newsitem.title: NORWAY: Statoil terminals to adopt new port dues.
newsitem.headline: Statoil terminals to adopt new port dues.

text.p: Modern tonnage will be treated more favourably by new port dues to be adopted in 1997 at Statoil's shipping terminals, Den norske stats oljeselskap AS said on Thursday.

Covering Mongstad near Bergen, Kaarstoe north of Stavanger and Kalundborg in Denmark, the new charges comprise a base fee set locally and a supplement of up to 30 percent, Statoil said in its Status Weekly newsletter.
The size of the extra payment depends on whether the vessel has a single or double hull and/or segregated ballast tanks (SBT).

Crude and product carriers calling at Mongstad must pay 5.20 crowns per net register ton in 1997. Dues were previously based on gross register tons. The change puts the payment more in line with cargo capacity, Statoil said.
A very large crude carrier (VLCC) of about 285,000 deadweight tonnes with single hull and no SBT is currently charged 593,000 crowns per call. This will rise to 722,000 crowns on January 1.
However, the due for a 124,000-tonne vessel with double hull and SBT will be reduced from about 220,000 crowns to 180,000 crowns.
"Curbing the use of ships that present the biggest pollution threat and cutting time spent by vessels in port are among the goals of this revision," said Mongstad port captain Kjell Heggertveit.
